title: This week in impeachment, in 5 minutes
text:
Here’s your recap of what happened this week in impeachment:

MONDAY: Former Trump officials point the finger at his lawyer

“I am not part of whatever drug deal Rudy and Mulvaney are cooking up,” and “Giuliani’s a hand grenade who’s going to blow everybody up.”

That’s what Fiona Hill, the former top Russia adviser at the White House, says her then-boss told her about Trump’s point people on Ukraine policy. She was the first of many current and former diplomats and officials who testified behind closed doors to House committees this week — despite White House orders not to. Hill testified that then-national security adviser John Bolton advised her to tell White House lawyers about all this to protect herself.

AD

AD

The accusation at the center of her testimony would be a running theme in the inquiry all week: That Rudolph W. Giuliani (who, remember, is Trump’s personal lawyer and not a government employee) was taking over Ukraine foreign policy from diplomats with decades of experience and politicizing it for Trump’s personal gain.

TUESDAY: Hunter Biden speaks

Hunter Biden told ABC News in the only interview he’s given since this story broke that he showed “poor judgment” and wouldn’t serve on any foreign boards if his dad, former vice president Joe Biden, were president, trying to clear the air about his work in Ukraine hours before the Democratic presidential debate. His position on the board of Ukrainian energy company Burisma Holdings ended up not being a major topic at the debate.

AD

George Kent, a former state Department official overseeing Ukraine testified he was worried Hunter Biden’s work could undermine the U.S.’s efforts, led by Biden, to encourage the Ukrainian government to address its own conflict of interest problems. This was in 2015, and Kent said he brought it up to the attention of then Vice President Biden’s office but was turned away by a staffer who said Biden was already overwhelmed by dealing with the terminal illness of his other son, Beau. There is still no evidence of wrongdoing by the Bidens in Ukraine, but Kent says he was worried about the appearance of it at the time.

WEDNESDAY: A top State official goes to Congress, days after he quit

This is probably as close to a defection as we have seen in this impeachment inquiry. A former adviser to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, told the House investigators that he quit his job just last week over his concerns about the Ukraine allegations and that career diplomats are getting thrown under the bus as it plays out. Michael McKinley worked closely with Pompeo, who is close to Trump, so he could have information about Pompeo’s role in Ukraine, The Post’s Carol Morello and John Hudson reported.

AD

AD

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) told his fellow Senate Republicans to get ready for a Senate impeachment trial, maybe around Thanksgiving and lasting until Christmas.

Meanwhile, a fourth person was arrested in a campaign finance case against major Trump donors. More broadly, the case accuses several Giuliani associates of scheming to illegally donate to a congressman as they tried to persuade the congressman to help get the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine ouster. Trump later removed the ambassador, upsetting a number of diplomats who would testify this week against him. “A diplomatic mugging,” a person familiar with McKinley’s testimony called the ousting of Marie Yovanovitch.

We learned more about Trump’s acting chief of staff’s role in enabling Trump to pressure Ukraine to do his political bidding. The Post reported that Mick Mulvaney gave the order to pause handing over the bipartisan-approved military aid to Ukraine, funds that some diplomats feared were being withheld in a quid pro quo for help on political matters important to Trump.

AD

AD

THURSDAY: ‘Get over it’

Thursday was probably the most damaging day for Trump’s presidency -- of the week, or maybe ever. In a press briefing at the White House, Mulvaney acknowledged something Trump had been denying: that the administration held up military aid for Ukraine in part because Trump wanted that country to investigate an allegation based on conspiracy theories that Ukraine was behind interference in the 2016 election.

“[Did] he also mention to me, in the past, that the corruption related to the DNC server?” Mulvaney says. “Absolutely, no question about that. But that’s it. And that’s why we held up the money..”

“What you just described is a quid pro quo,” a reporter says, giving him an opportunity to clarify if it wasn’t. “We do that all the time on foreign policy,” Mulvaney answers in a pretty unmistakable affirmation. A few hours of White House panic later, Mulvaney tried to mop things up in a statement, saying the press “misconstrued” his comments.

AD

AD

On the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue, one of Trump’s top diplomats working on Ukraine matters, Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland told Congress he was uncomfortable with how the White House appeared to politicize Ukraine relations and that Giuliani was taking directions to do so from the president himself. That’s despite the fact Sondland comes across in text messages as one of Trump’s top defenders throughout the summer, as he, Giuliani and diplomats negotiated with Ukraine’s newly elected president to score an investigation into the Bidens.

With more scrutiny about his role working alongside Sondland on Ukraine, Energy Secretary Rick Perry informed Trump he’ll resign by the end of the year. Democrats have subpoenaed Perry for documents about his involvement in that July call between Trump and Ukraine’s president. Perry acknowledges urging Trump to make the call, but says he was focused on energy issues. He denies that his resignation has anything to do with the Ukraine inquiry.

FRIDAY: More potentially damaging testimony is coming

It’s clear Trump wasn’t happy with what Mulvaney admitted. “I think he clarified it,” Trump said Friday, describing Mulvaney’s statement.

Congress called for five new witnesses to testify next week, including the acting ambassador to Ukraine, Bill Taylor, who is quoted in text messages calling it “crazy to withhold security assistance for help with a political campaign.”

AD
description: From top aides turning on the Trump administration to acknowledging a quid pro quo, it was the most damaging yet for Trump
authors: Reporter For The Fix Covering Congress
